title: 111_hr5698
content: PROTECTION OF EMPLOYEES FROM RETALIATION BY THEIR EMPLOYER FOR COOPERATING IN INVESTIGATIONS. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to include a new section prohibiting retaliation. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to include a new section prohibiting retaliation against employees for reporting violations, refusing to participate in noncompliant conduct, or providing information related to the Act. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to include protections for employees who report violations, refuse to participate in noncompliant conduct, provide information related to the Act, testify in proceedings, or assist in any actions to carry out the Act. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 now protects employees who report violations, refuse to participate in noncompliant conduct, provide information, testify in proceedings, or assist in carrying out the Act through legal actions governed by specific rules and procedures. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 provides protection for employees who report violations or refuse to participate in noncompliant conduct. Legal actions can be taken under specific rules and procedures, including seeking district court review within 90 days of receiving a final determination by the Secretary of Labor. Amendments made by the Act are included in references to the law. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 protects employees from retaliation for reporting violations or refusing to participate in noncompliant conduct. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act has been amended to include a new section prohibiting retaliation. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 and the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act protect employees from retaliation for reporting violations or refusing to participate in noncompliant conduct. No person or employer can discriminate against an employee for notifying authorities of violations, refusing to engage in noncompliant conduct, or providing information related to job duties. Employees are protected from retaliation for reporting violations or refusing to participate in noncompliant conduct under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 and the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. This includes refusing to engage in noncompliant conduct, providing information related to job duties, testifying in proceedings, or assisting in any actions related to the Acts. Employees protected from retaliation for reporting violations or refusing to participate in noncompliant conduct under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 and the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act can bring an enforcement action if they allege discrimination by an employer. This action is governed by specific rules, procedures, legal burdens of proof, and remedies. District court review can be sought within 90 days of receiving a final determination by the Secretary of Labor.
